{{also|Fliegen}} ==German== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|de|goh|fliogan}}, from {{inh|de|gem-pro|*fleuganą}}, from {{inh|de|ine-pro|*pleuk-}}. Compare {{cog|nl|vliegen}}, Low German {{m|de|flegen}}, English {{m|en|fly}}, Danish {{m|da|flyve}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|de|/ˈfliːɡŋ̩/|/ˈfliːɡən/}} * {{audio|de|De-fliegen.ogg|audio (Germany)}} * {{audio|de|De-at-fliegen.ogg|audio (Austria)}} ===Verb=== {{de-verb-strong|class=2|fliegt|flog|geflogen|past subjunctive=flöge|auxiliary=both}} # {{lb|de|intransitive|auxiliary ''sein''}} to [[fly]]; to [[travel]] by [[air]] #* '''2010''', ''{{w|Der Spiegel}}'', issue [http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/index-2010-52.html 52/2010], page 16: #*: Passagiere, die aus den USA nach Europa '''fliegen''' und dort umsteigen, sollen ab dem 1. April im Transitbereich nicht mehr kontrolliert werden. #*:: It is planned that passengers who fly from the United States to Europe and change planes there are not checked in the transit area anymore after April 1. # {{lb|de|intransitive|figuratively|auxiliary ''sein''}} to [[rush]]; to [[fly]]; to go quickly # {{lb|de|transitive|auxiliary ''haben''}} to [[fly]]; to [[pilot]] # {{lb|de|transitive|auxiliary ''haben''}} to [[transport]] by air # {{lb|de|intransitive|colloquial|auxiliary ''sein''}} to [[get the axe]], to get [[kicked out]] # {{lb|de|intransitive|colloquial|auxiliary ''sein''}} to [[fall]]; to fall down ====Conjugation==== {{de-conj-strong|flieg|flog|geflogen|hs|||flög|a}} * In early modern German, the 2nd and 3rd persons singular present and the imperative singular were alternatively ''du'' {{m|de|fleugst}}, ''er'' {{m|de|fleugt}}, ''{{m|de|fleug}}! ====Derived terms==== * {{l|de|abfliegen}} * {{l|de|Flieger}} * {{l|de|herabfliegen}} * {{l|de|hochfliegen}} * {{l|de|rausfliegen}} * {{l|de|überfliegen}} * {{l|de|unterfliegen}} * {{l|de|verfliegen}} * {{l|de|vorbeifliegen}} * {{l|de|wegfliegen}} ===Further reading=== * {{R:Duden}}
